replies.author: @d007ization
replies.text:
@templecreations2351 It's been 3 months and youtube is horrible at notifying people of comment responses but I feel the need to say some things.

Calling the people who commit atrocities humans only "absolves" them of anything if you think there's some kind of inherent goodness to being a human or to leading an ordinary life. Looking at history, there clearly isn't.

Your anger is understandable, it should be respected and it's not a virtue. Correcting injustices done to you by punishing the wrongdoer is an inherently human response. But who does it help, really? 
You're right, if someone hurt my family or if I spent my entire life living under the thumb of a seemingly distinct group of people,  of course I'd feel rage. Of course I wouldn't listen to reason. But so what? That wouldn't make me right, it would make me a dangerous liability, as any isolated angry man is.
We can't ignore such angry men, of course and it's not quite true that their feelings are completely counterproductive, as they help them and their loved ones deal with their trauma as well as highlight injustices that societies should work to rectify but(!) we also try to placate them is because if we don't they'll likely form into some kind of militia with no accountability. 

And now, to exemplify why people are telling you that your thinking is wrong.
1) These people are committing atrocities against us, we must do something about it!
2) Any action we take against them is completely justified, no matter how punitive! Brutal deaths, torture, they're doing the same to us!


3) Ok so it turns out, people aren't okay with us brutally killing their friends and family so they've exacted revenge on us, for this reason, let's start preemptively killing the friends and family of the bad group too.

replies.author: @templecreations2351
replies.text:
@d007ization  im glad you took the time to lay out your position. Let me honor that by laying out mine. i have kids, and i know what innocence looks like. There is an inherent innocence in humans and there is an inherent value and moral goodnesss in preserving that innocence as much as posssible. Naturally, the brutal conditions of nature have turned man into beast, set them upon each other, out of desperation at first and yet for many, malice and pleasure is derived soon thereafter. Innocence is lost,
perverted and raped. 

I do not consider my anger a virtue, in fact i fully aknowledge that it is partially kin to the abomination that i wish to do away with, yet the key difference is that it is indeed justified and understandable, and i would argue inevitable. It is the natural opposite reaction to the dark imperfections of this world. You ask who this anger helps? This anger that drives the natural human response of seeking justice? It helps victims find closure, it helps future victims avoid crossing paths with the degenerates that chose to victimise others because they were afraid of becoming victims themselves. It is a motivating force that gives you strength to be selfless and ferocious against the wicked.

This nihilistic form of moral relativism where one asks ‚Äúwho does it help, really?‚Äù I find to be little more than a rationalised helplesness, and I refuse to be helpless. I reject the belief that it helps no one. I am batman. Jokes aside, i find it unreasonable to tell oneself that there is a rational reason why rage is unnecessary in face of genuine injustice. As you mentioned before, it is the natural response. The mere fact that you can rationalise about it, doesn‚Äôt automatically make it invalid, and unworthy of being acted upon. It would not only make you right to act against genuine oppression, to stand for those who cannot protect themselves from abuse, rape, pillaging, etc. it would make you moral. 

I am aware of the irational nature of such a path, and its kinship to the very forces of abuse and oppresion it seeks to destroy. I am aware of the pitfall of rage consuming purpose and becoming blind, effectively becoming the same thing it set out to destroy. Qanon is a good example of this. Certainly, it is a volatile thing. But in my opinion, that is precisely why rational thought and reasoning should not reject our natural impulses of righteous rage. It should seek to temper it, to direct it and to realise its destiny in destroying all those who seek to take the light and innocence away from the world. 

A bully cannot be rationalised with, a bully cannot be pleaded with, or even bargained with. A bully will understand only one thing and that is might, fuelled by righteous rage against the injustices they subject the world to. And if we want to get past human oppression, abuse, rape, tyranny, we must not render ourselves impotent of a response by using our rational capacities to established a rationalised helplessness, we must use our rational capacity to employ our justified anger as a mount, and trample all those who chose to spit on their own innocence and humanity beneath its fiery hooves. Destroy all those who chose to build their joy on the tears and wailing of families torn apart, peoples enslaved, daughters defiled. It is inevitable, it is angers purpose and destiny.

The sooner we accept that anger is part of the equation, the sooner we may learn how to master it and not be blindly lead by it. Like shaolin warriors, who professed love and harmony with all living thing and yet had to employ their anger of seeing their homes and peoples pillaged, in order to perfect tools of righteous retribution. 

We cannot sit idly by and calmly rationalise the monsters of humanity away. This is precisely the sentiment that allowed hitler to come to power and commit the atrocities that he did. Never again ‚ö°Ô∏è‚ö°Ô∏è‚ö°Ô∏è

replies.author: @Darth_Insidious
replies.text:
@templecreations2351 To right wrongs it is justice that is required, not vengeance. Vengeance is deeply personal and afflicted with the sins of man. A man seeking vengeance wishes to see his enemy experience the pain enacted upon him, and thus brings unessessary suffering into the world. Justice, however, is ideally impartial. Defined by the rule of law, and judged by the citizens of the nation, justice seeks to deliver impersonal punishment that the majority of society can agree is just. Vengeance will turn a people against each other, prompting them to enact suffering on one for the actions of another. 

The night of broken glass was a movement of vengeance against the Jewish people for the assassination of a German diplomat by a French Jew. Justice would see the Jew brought to trail and be judged for his actions. Vengeance would see the slaughter of his people to cause him great anguish.

You liken yourself to Batman, but the reason why he refuses to kill is because he believes that it would lower him to thier level. He delivers evildoers to the justice system to see thier crimes stand before trial, to have them be judged by the masses instead of by himself. Perhaps you agree with me.

The reason why justice is important is because nobody can claim to be the wise king, perfect judge of morality. Humans are deeply flawed creatures who easily fall prey to possession by personal demons or collective evil. It should be expected that humans are not born good or neutral, but tribal animals who must work to adopt morals and avoid possession by the collective will. The nazis rose because the collective will shifted towards them. The general consensus amoung Germans was that of humiliation and exploitation, which was aimed at Europe and perceived traitors to the country such as the Jews. The man who promised to set things right and bring vengeance upon Germany's enemies ended up taking power.

Hundreds of innocent Iranian lives were lost because US citizens wanted vengence for 9/11. Many Iranians sought vengeance against the west in turn. Both sides felt righteous fury for the wrongs done to them and thier people.

After WWII the allies did not seek to  enact vengence upon the German people for the evil they helped nurture. They sought to bring justice upon those who did the most wrong, and then extend compassion to the German people, as though possessed by the hatred of the Jews, they were only human. Doing so prevented the unnecessary humiliation and suffering from the first war.

Evil is as rooted in humanity as good. Even a relatively moral man can find himself chanting for blood along with the mob. Seeing those who commit atrocity as human makes us aware of the fact that evil can easily take root within our own hearts.

replies.author: @GlobstersMessenger
replies.text:
I think it's worth considering as an aside that, this doesn't mean we have to specifically go out of our way to portray specific murderers and other rather "monstrous" individuals as people with depth, but rather to keep the fact that everyday humans can end up performing these terrible things in our minds when creating and interpreting real events and media.

It's not that the victims of murderers (familities and friends of those murdered, for instance) have to personally deeply consider the humanity of those murderers - why should they have this arbitrary moral duty thrust upon them? -but when people do make efforts to analyze these people, that shouldn't immediately provoke accusation of "justification" or "apologism", there's room to consider why people do these things. The issue comes up when this is used to justify claims of "innocence while being guilty". 

Y'know, "Yeah they genocided those civilians, but they were *pressured* to do it by the state, they didn't have a choice." vs "They genocided those civilians in collaboration with a violent coercive authoratarian state." One apologizes and makes excuses, the other describes what occured without apologism *or* excuse. One tries to minimize, the other lays bare the moral reality.

replies.author: @SourDonut99
replies.text:
@Ninjaananas what the Nazis did was indeed evil but the question is. Did the Nazis themselves find it evil? 

The truth is, many of the Nazis didn't think their actions were evil at all and many others did find it evil but it was justified. The bottom line is they think they are of good moral standing while carrying out atrocities. 

Very few people are actually psychopaths who know they are doing evil but dont care. Very few people are also sociopaths who don't see their actions as evil at all. Psychologists debate weather if it's even possible to have a true psychopath. 

You can't just dismiss the entire German people a sociopaths or psychopaths. These are incredibly rare disorders. The Nazis were just common German people who were probably convinced their actions were righteous or justified. It's important to understand how they may have come to that conclusion so we don't repeat it ourselves.

But one element I want to point out is the Nazis thought they were moral. That means you or I could easily think of ourselves as moral but on the side we can totally be hiding skeletons in our closet. The thing is, we wouldn't even realize it because we think we are morally right. We could be part of a ideological bubble making fallacious arguments about the opposing side and trying to get them cancelled with smears and lies. We could be writing for CNN or Fox News. None of that stuff is even close to what the Nazis did but it's just ways we can act dishonestly and still think we are morally right. We have a tendency to follow the heard in this regard so we can easily slip into the far right crowd or far left crowd without even realizing it. That's what happened to the Nazis.

replies.author: @felixleidinger1670
replies.text:
@Ninjaananas You are right to a certain extent:
You cant explain away personal responsibility over an action taken.
But you speak from a superior, historical perspective. And you dont seem to understand how fascism works. Its a totally different social paradigm, under it we wouldnt be able to discuss this topic, not only due to obvious censorship, but due to it probably never coming up or you having no incentive to discuss it because it would be easier for survival or social standing or even for your worldview and personal pride- which in this case, quite different from more free societies, would be closely linked- not to do so, thus it being disincentivised for the majority of the population.

First: to make the "moral" descision one would be able to get access towards an objective truth. The information around the descision free from manipulation. As long as the Nazis controlled the media, people had only access to the truth the propaganda ministry put out. Add to that criminal charges like "Wehrkraftzersetzung" "undermining defence force" or "F√ºhrerbeleidigung" "insulting the leader" or criminalising listening to unchecked "foreign propaganda" like non-german radio stations or even music.
Thus making any effective public positioning towards the real crimes by the NS regime who tried their best to keep up an air of plausible deniability- really hard. To a point where it would be suicide, nobody will listen to somebody willing to commit suicide. You will be categorised as a maniac, a fanatic, out of a sheer need for self protection which I will cover in the next point. Also- who would start such a movement? Who can be trusted not to be a Gestapo spy? Rooting out "internal enemies" was the first thing the Nazis did, people kept their opinions close at heart and all the public- at least through every channel of gaining information- seemed to support them, down to a level of a party-controlled neighboorhood guard which made even personal exchanges of non-approved information rather difficult.

Second, that descision requires freedom to make said choice. Because besides the first paragraph people SAW what was going on. Rumours WERE going around. Why did only a point of a percentage of people act on this? Because it was easier not to act to keep up the official lifestyle and deny repression. It was easier on the conscience because it denies personal responsibility in a "Volksgemeinschaft" kind of "we are all in it together system" if one imagines crimes dont happen- remember, the Nazis ruled with nominal democratic legitimacy. If the crimes committed and the surpression system around them become so horriffic at a certain point people will just... ignore them, either to be able to sleep at night by forgetting what "our guys" are actually doing or just to be able to live ones own life without persecution. 

Its all foreign propaganda! As if such a thing was possible! We are the good guys!

This gets accompanied by subconscious guilt,- people arent that stupid and usually have a conscience- which is solved by neglect, vain justifications like "they do it to" and aggression against people who speak out because they became a threat for you and your worldview that may expose the dark you managed to hide beneath a thin sheet of normality. 
It basically tearing apart the social and the private- your social life is under foreign controll, all the input you receive is normed- this will shift you as well, make you more easily controlled. Those are basic triggers of human social life and their controll is often outside your own sphere of influence. If you grew up with a certain definition of pride for example, that pride can be used to manipulate you if the critical information channels blancing this are closed. Or with a definition of "us" vs a definition of "them". Its the subjectivity were human conscience is hackable.

Also you must consider the role of individuals in this. Hannah Ahrendt famously wrote of the banality of evil if you are aware of that concept- how far is a cog in the evil machine able to act evil itself? Sure, the head, purpose and controll of every part of the machine can be considered as such, but was the train driver who had to transport "prisoners" eastward to the KZs explicitly evil for doing his job? What about the soldier and the firing order against civilians- if refusing it is possible but frowned upon? What if said soldier was in a "Strafbattallion" and unable to controll his situation? Is the KZ prisoner manifacturing V2s in order to receive food and not be send to the deathcamps evil because he enabled the bombing of London? The Kapos, were they evil?  Its a question of the liberty of millions of individuals to make thousands of individual moral choices daily- you can cry "liberty or death all you want, but death is what you certainly would receive-, the subjective categorisation of that choice, how it was carried out, and why. 

This requires constant monitoring of ones self and the society at large, defences against the erosion of democracy into fascism. 
I would heartily recommend reading "The Wave"- a story that explains how people slip into such a societal gridlock that enables this shutdown of reason that you so correctly identify. Highlighting this doesnt deny the individual responsibility of the people involved, but it explains how those systems come to pass. Its like committing crimes when drunk- under fascism people get drunk on some mythos and commit brutal acts in the name of a collective they wouldnt do otherwise, because under the system they live in, it benefits them and offers the temptation of an alternative reality that denies any personal responsibility.
But there is also responsibility in getting so drunk that we committed the crime in the first place.
 If we can understand the drug, we can prevent people getting drunk. Prevent people getting drunk and you may prevent the crime.

On the other hand, pretending you are unable to commit a crime because you are always reasonable is the first step in getting drunk. It negates critical thought for pride. If there is no motivator to question oneself, people will act on their worst impulses, especially if empathy is artificially surpressed- for example by racist ideology, even under the flimsiest pretence one is able to commit horrible acts if one can pretend that they are necessary.

So its important to identify the system that led to the crimes in order to prevent the crimes, not bash anyone around for complex individual choices they probably werent able to make to the extent you would like to think. 
And sry for me saying this, but if you are not one in a thousand, you would just go with the crowd. In their shoes, you probably will take the same actions because quite often, the rational choice in the moment was more concerned with staying sane or alive or simply being able to sleep at night, to protect your family. Your conscience isnt your only motivator if you have bigger responsibilities. 

There are forces in human society that go far beyond the actions of individuals, and fascism is a system that denies individuality contrary to the narrative in the first place.

replies.author: @falleithani5411
replies.text:
Perhaps not a reasonable purpose, but a practical one. Separating the two makes both less likely to flee. The latter won't leave without the former, and the former are less capable.

It also means that both can be given less food and such, without causing as much discord. The latter can be told the former need it more, while the former are, again, defenseless. If the latter could _see_ the former, that wouldn't work.

Lots of other stuff too.

A few points to why this is:
German and English share the same linguistic ancestry, but English ist much easier. for example English doesn‚Äôt have grammatic genders (is this the correct term?) or cases that are expressed within the noun and the English sentence structure seams easier to me compared to German.
We are confronted with the English language early on in school and most movies etc are produced in English.
German has a rather large vocabulary with very precise words to describe something. Those of us who listen or speak English often tend to search for the most accurate translation for the precise German word we would use..
But while it is easy to articulate our thoughts in the English language, the pronunciation is the tricky part. Dan does quite a good job there..

replies.author: @justiziabelle
replies.text:
weirdly enough, it wasn't brought up yet, so here are my two cents. 

another explanation is that nowadays in germany we learn english in school from third grade onwards (up to genX it was still from 5th grade onwards), so for years of school we learned english in school several times a week and then of course we are also inundated in english in our every day lives be it through advertisements, company logos, pop culture and the internet, all of these solidify or even enhance german's grasp of the english language. 
that being said, daniel's english skills are definitely above average compared to other germans, but if i remember correctly he also lived in some english speaking country for a time, so that shouldn't be that surprising. 
also, you will most likely not read from or listen to germans a lot who aren't very good in english, because they simply  choose not to speak or write in it very often, if it can be helped, 
which of course doesn't exactly help either, i guess.

for an american or a brit the situation is obviously quite different. in most cases i presume german is not a mandatory subject and they actually need to choose german as a secondary or tertiary language in school and it will also be way less prevalent in their every day lives.

replies.text:
‚Äã@DrCruel On what planet do you live in that makes you think the US has ever had a problem with NOT meddling in country affairs???

Since it's founding, and these are only a select example of countries, the US has had a direct influence in forcefully changing regimes in countries such as Nicaragua, Panama, Cuba, Honduras, Iran, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Syria, Venezuela, and most recently Bolivia. At what point did America not go "far enough" with this?

replies.author: @DrCruel
replies.text:
@michaelweir9666 You apparently have never heard of "containment." If the Bolsheviks went into a country and started murdering non-socialists, then we and the rest of the free world would act against them. That's "meddling" in the affairs of Left fascists, which I have absolutely no problem with.

The real problem is that the US would only do so hesitantly. When Left fascist groups cause civil strife in the name of their "revolution" (for example, Marxist narco-guerrillas in Columbia, starvation in Venezuela, armed supressin of the people by Sandinistas in Nicaragua, Evo Morales and his drug dealing allies in Bolivia, etc), people starve and people die. This tends to get people in these countries moving north, where it's safer - and where they can escape from socialist criminals. This is the 800 lb "guerrilla" that America's immigration laws don't address, and that Left fascist sympathizers in the West never talk about.

replies.author: @michaelweir9666
replies.text:
‚Äã@DrCruel "You apparently have never heard of "containment." If the Bolsheviks went into a country and started murdering non-socialists, then we and the rest of the free world would act against them. That's "meddling" in the affairs of Left fascists, which I have absolutely no problem with."

This argument died decades ago with the Cold War, and for good reason. It was always full of shit. What 'freedom' was won out of Iran through deposing Prime Minister Mossadegh and replacing him with a corrupt monarch? Not a damn thing, and you know it. What it did is give them a dictator who was willing to sell out the country's people to provide valuable resources to the open market at a premium. I think it goes doubly amusing how you try to blame the US's problems on "left fascists" (This term means absolutely nothing, it's a negative connotation with no tether to reality) when it was the actions such as this that brought about other country's hatred for the US, and decades later still send shockwaves we have yet to recover from.

There is no justification for things like Reagan's involvement with the Contras, a covert decision that not only did more harm to the people we claimed to want to help than good, but also did harm to our very own country both domestically and internationally. I don't care what bloody revolution is happening in  a country that is not our own, if we wanted to actually help the situation then we could have handled it completely different. It's not about helping, though. It's about games of geopolitics, special interests, and corrupt or incompetent leadership.

I'm also wondering what planet you live on where you convince yourself there was any good reason for the assisted military coup against Evo Morales, a democratically elected president, loved by his people, who committed the terrible crime of not considering the coca plant within Bolivia's borders a target for the disastrous embarrassment that is the War on Drugs, a decision which by the way was widely popular throughout the country. I'm sorry, but when you start making decision based purely on if they are beneficial for the USA and not respecting policies made by an autonomous country with its own ideas and goals, you demonstrate the reality it is not "policing the world" that the USA engages in, but unambiguous imperialism. Any country that is prepared to damn an entire nation of people to dictatorship for the sake of resources and personal gain is the stuff of evil, the kind of force we're supposed to be making a stand against. It's this very act of casual, brutal destabilization we've committed on such a regular basis for decades that has brought the world into the state it is now. You treat socialist uprisings like a force of nature, a freak accident that is neither explainable nor brought up by any consequence of the abuse of power. This is not even exclusive to socialists, but fundamentalist and reactionary terror cells that we personally fund and train, doors we have personally opened, that have participated in the utter destruction of any hope we may have had in bringing democracy and peace to these corners of the world. Now the chickens are coming home to roost, and there's no more room to blame someone else for the quagmire we've steeped ourselves in.

I want to ask you an honest question. Do you believe the USA would or has ever committed to a change in regime that they did not stand to directly benefit from? We're both reasonable people, I think we can safely agree that there is no such thing as a 'benevolent' foreign intervention done by any one country. If something required genuine humanitarian work, it could usually be more easily carried out through the UN where we as a single country would not need to burden ourselves with the sole budget, logistics, or diplomatic collateral that would accompany it. 

When you strip away the facade of what we claim our foreign policy stands for, so too does the narrative they try to push. It becomes at that point difficult to trust anything that is stated to be done for the good of the country, and for good reason.

replies.author: @davidmurray3542
replies.text:
@C.1212-c4d well the assertion that it's a mathematical certainty has a few flaws: 1) while it's generally true that birth rates are lower in "Western" countries compared with the Middle East, the difference is only around 30% (~1.8 compared to ~2.4) and birth rates in the Middle East have dropped dramatically in the last 50 years with predictions that they will continue to drop; 2) immigrants from countries with higher birth rates won't necessarily retain those - there are economic (e.g. raising children is more expensive) and cultural factors (e.g. access to contraceptives and sex education is higher); 3) The "native" population is much larger than the immigrant population so it will be generations before they even approach equity, even assuming birth and immigration rates remain constant; 4) all of this presupposes that there will be no integration or inter-relation between immigrants and the "native" population / culture.

As for why it might be considered racist, language like "importing" is a loaded term implying that there's some intentional moving of these people when in fact they're fleeing conflict and instability and/or just hoping for a better life, plus the suggestion that changing demographics are even a problem is a bit xenophobic. Often these arguments are accompanied by further unsubstantiated claims along the lines of immigrants bringing crime or abusing welfare (which I appreciate that you've not done).

People who come here legally may or may not be desperate, but by following the process they have shown that they are not willing to sacrifice their principles to get ahead. They are worthy of being here, more worthy than most Americans no less.

The people who will hide out in the desert, jump fences, steal identities, and avoid the state are not worthy of being here. They are proving through action that they are selfish and immoral. Most of all, I hate how the whole country, or even the whole world feels compelled to talk about this problem when they don't even live here. author: @nataschavisser573
text: I guess Carl does not know that his own country ran notorious networks of concentration camps in which tens of thousands of non-combatants, mostly mothers and young children, died. They did it in South Africa during the late 19th/early twentieth century and repeated this dubious accomplishment after WW2 in Kenya.  Concentration camps do not have to be extermination camps for mass deaths to occur since neglect is sufficient. Crowding people into small areas and then not providing them with clean clothing, basic hygiene, proper nutrition and medical care leads to sickness and death.

replies.author: @aperson6505
replies.text: Ever heard of Martha Gellhorn? Her journalistic piece describing Dachau, a concentration camp (not death camp) is harrowing, showing the poor conditions and outright inhumane experimentation that occurred there. I almost feel like Auschwitz has clouded the public perception of what makes a CC, as only a few of the German camps were actively about extermination when forced labour and more were leading causes of death.

text: My friends often talk about the protagonist problem - each person's brain rewrites their world view until they become the good guy

replies.author: @domhuckle
replies.text: @Munchausenification it's something that's always been present I think - the brain is just hard wired to find excuses for our behaviour to prevent any of us from feeling like the bad guy. "there's always two sides to a story" and all that

replies.author: @Munchausenification
replies.text: @domhuckle That is for sure a strong argument. Ill let you know if I can think of an argument against it at some point.

replies.author: @domhuckle
replies.text: @Munchausenification for sure. Since I was little, I've seen that there's a strong push back among people against saying you don't know something. Even bigger to admitting you were in the wrong. That's only gotten bigger with newspeak apologies like being sorry that the other person felt harmed, rather than sorry for the harm you caused. I think it's subtle shifts like this which help the brain distance itself from it's own faults. That's why addiction is so hard to deal with - it's so easy to blame something else; find an excuse to behaviour. Maybe there'll be a pendulum swing, who knows?

replies.author: @Munchausenification
replies.text: @domhuckle Do you think part of the protagonist problem being that less people are reading books? You have probably experienced the wonderful feeling of getting lost in the universe of the book you are reading. That is an interesting example with addiction. Yes I can for sure see how it is much easier to blame drugs or other factors rather than put the blame on yourself.

replies.author: @Zapdos7471
replies.text:
Rather than a problem of narrative bias I think of it in terms of emotional security. People with insecurities and persecution complexes are the ones who can‚Äôt admit their mistakes, and we are living through a period where both are prolific.

Also, somewhat related, when a problem is reduced to a binary there is an appealing logical fallacy that becomes available: instead of proving themself right they only have to prove the other side wrong. This completely removes the need for self evaluation and creates a cognitive blind spot.

I‚Äôve found that people who do this tip their hand when they stop saying ‚ÄúI‚Äù statements entirely.

replies.text: @mattmattmatt131313 More people should learn about language implicatures. If a ship¬¥s first mate had written in a log "Today it was a good day, the captain is not drunk". The implicit meaning in that sentences is that most days he is drunk and then the Captain would be very upstet. It can be very well that the captain is a sober man and what he wrote would be true, but then he wouldn¬¥t have a reason to put that information because it is irrelevant. If you write something like "I wouldn¬¥t even rape you" there a few implicatures: the first is "you are not worthy of rape (the "even"), which is one of the worse things you can say to another person. It means I see as having so few worth as a human being that I wouldn¬¥t been defile myself with you by raping you.The other implicature is "I would rape you if the circumstances were different, so "if you were a little more attractive, for example, I would consider raping you to not be beneath me". Sargon might not have wanted to convey those meaning, but those are the meaning conveye in that "joke", which fuck, those are some of the worst thoughts you can direct to another human being and totally lacking any semblance of empathy. You can say the media misrepresented what he said and he in no way meant to say that the Captain was a drunk man, that it was a joke and in no way an attack on the Captain, but he wrote what he wrote and probably he new what he was writing. So, ehre the same, either Carl is so stupid and doesn¬¥t know how sentences in his native langauge work (which is a posibility, I won¬¥t deny it) or he purposefully threw one of the most demeaning things you can to a person. Given that later he said "If I had a few beers I could cave in." I would pick the second (but I won¬¥t rule out the first, both can be true at the same tim).

@saoirsecameron - I can't speak for the majority of Americans of Native American descent. But the majority of my close relatives don't fervently oppose "illegal immigration" of Central and South Americans. I have one Fox News uncle, out of 5 uncles and 1 aunt, who might. And then I have some distant Fox News relatives who probably do.

The rest of us have empathy or sympathy for people who are fleeing violence and/or poverty. And we notice the hypocrisy of of people getting so bent out of shape over legal formalities, considering what the U.S., Great Britain, France, Spain, etc. and some of their people did to Native Americans in what is now the U.S. And then, of course, the Trump has even implemented the policy of treating all lawful asylum seekers as illegal immigrants and separating them from their children if they have any. But these people aren't as upset about the Trump violating the U.S. Constitution and international law and separating children from their parents as they are about regular people crossing the border illegally (which is just a misdemeanor, anyway).

@300bpm ¬†well... there are two ways into dictature. Consider it like a ring where you sit at the diamond. One way goes to the left, and one way to the right. One way wants to structure everything, one want's to structure nothing. In one you get too centralized organizations up for the power grab (left), one leds to no opposition to the most powerful (right). In the end it doesn't matter. Democracy and freedom are a delicate marblegame and it takes energy to take the marble in the middle such that it allows us to  keep things like humanity and compassion, which are the first things dictators, left or right, wanna take from you because if they succed you become their accomplice.

1. America has sled so far to the right that concentration camps become a thing. Could it be the left? No... they are not in charge and also the main shtick of the governing partyin USA  is freedom at all cost (including freedom). Freedom however needs boundaries. Structures on the other Hand need adaptability. 
2. The very first thing a dictator of any of both kind would do is point at the other side,  scream BUT the Leeeft... ( ...the Riiighht)  to distract from their own misdeeds. Of course they also need their accomplices, which do it for them.

So... i answer the implicit question in your post, even though it was whataboutism: Your point is valid, however not in the moment. If the marblegame tilts heavy to the right already, pushing it even further won't help. USA and other countries have pulled so far right already that they start asking of their citizens to forget their human core values. Don't become an accomplice. replies.author: @UserJWR
replies.text:
@MrJaaaaake Just saying "we are different" is not good enough. You have to actually show how the two cultures are different from each other in ways that are relevant to the matter at hand. You could argue that Germany uses a civil code and anglo-american law is based on case law, and maybe that is relevant to how racism can spread within the state and legal system (even though I don't see the argument there, I am not a law expert though). You could argue that anglo-american culture is more individualistic than german culture and the individual traditionally holds more power over the state (except when they are black and enslaved, I guess). You could also say that anglo-american culture is more profit-oriented (by virtue of its individualism) and a genocide or at least abuse of power against minorities is more likely, if it profits those in charge. 

I haven't seen Sargon's response video and I'm not gonna bother, but I highly doubt that he made these or similar arguments. "We are different" is not an argument, if you don't show how these differences are relevant.

text:
"[...] The inquisitors [of the Church of Om] stopped work twice a day for coffee. Their mugs, which each man had brought from home, were grouped around the kettle on the hearth of the central furnace which incidentally heated the irons and knives.

They had legends on them like A Present From the Holy Grotto of Ossory, or To The World‚Äôs Greatest Daddy. Most of them were chipped, and no two of them were the same.

And there were the postcards on the wall. It was traditional that, when an inquisitor went on holiday, he‚Äôd send back a crudely colored woodcut of the local view with some suitably jolly and risqu√© message on the back. And there was the pinned-up tearful letter from Inquisitor First Class Ishmale ‚ÄúPop‚Äù Quoom, thanking all the lads for collecting no fewer than seventy-eight obols for his retirement pension and the lovely bunch of flowers for Mrs. Quoom, indicating that he‚Äôd always remember his days in No. 3 pit, and was looking forward to coming in and helping out any time they were short-handed.


And it all meant this: that there are hardly any excesses of the most crazed psychopath that cannot easily be duplicated by a normal, kindly family man who just comes in to work every day and has a job to do."


-- Terry Pratchett, from Small Gods

Jonas Pell Why are the detention centers not concentration camps? I mean, they serve the exact same purpose as any other concentration camp build in the past centuries. Are we calling a spade a spoon because once a spade was used to dig a grave so now we only associate spades with bad things?
Because that's what happened to the term "concentration camp"...anyone who thinks "concentration camp" means  "Nazi Death Prison" is entirely uninformed about what they were, are, and mean.

Even the Nazis destinguished between them...why shouldn't we? Auschwitz wasn't just "one big death camp", the Death part was Auschwitz II, or Auschwitz-Birkenau, the rest of the Auschwitz facilities had different purposes, but "Death Camps" were purpose build and VERY different from concentration camps.

A concentration camp is any facility to "concentrate" and hold a specific type of people for more effective processing by local authorities...

I mean, the brits invented the concept back in the collonial times, I bet they didn't equate them to "only use for mass murder".

But I guess using the grossly misinformed definition is the new MO for the supposedly "well educated, fact based" society that prides itself on it's "impirical logic" and "facts" or something.

I don't know why someone would call the detention facilities concentration camps, but they are technically not wrong. Because a concentration camp is just that...a temporary detention facility build for a specific purpose.

replies.text: What's your opinion on the internet ultrasimplifying the mental issues every human has?

replies.author: @SoPsyched
replies.text: @fulcrum2951 it's a common phenomenon. Psychology is fascinating to most people, since it offers insight, so naturally psychological terms (like depression, anxiety, even schizophrenia, etc.) spread among laymen and women and the meaning gets distorted. I personally welcome the dialogue. The more people are open to discussion, the more likely they can change and take control over their future. As for the phenomenon, that nowadays "everyone" claims to have e.g. depression and anxiety: it doesn't bother me. I only feel sorry for those who _really_ suffer from it (got properly diagnosed and are in treatment for those conditions) since they put in the effort and work on their mental health. People who claim those clinical labels for themselves but weren't diagnosed and are not in treatment, just make others with those diagnoses look bad imo. It's like claiming to have a toothache, but not going to a dentist and rather bringing it up as an excuse for most things. Mental health takes work, just like physical health. If someone doesn't want to work on it, they should refrain from using clinical terms... just my 2 cents üíù

replies.author: @discountchocolate4577
replies.text:
@bonda_racing3579 What you call "crony capitalism" or "corporatism" is still capitalism, it's just no longer competitive or "free market" capitalism. Capitalists still own and control most of the businesses, the factories, the banks, the land, etc. etc., and they still withhold that control of capital to coerce labor from those who own less property and to extract surplus from that labor to make a profit. Under these conditions, even this "degenerated" form of capitalism is still capitalism.

Furthermore, under an initially competitive capitalism, i.e. under conditions that have rarely been observable since before the gilded age, when (plundered) natural resources and land were still abundant in North America, even in a scenario where all firms start off on approximately equal footing, firms that make the most profits and grow the most enter later periods with asymmetric advantages and gradually increase their market shares until in the absence of sufficient regulation against it they become oligopolistic firms, and barriers to entry by newcomers are nigh-insurmountable. This was one of the features that emerged from the gilded age, from the 1870s until monopolies and oligopolies were partly "busted" in the 1910s, the same period during which these increasingly corporate businesses, along with imperialist capitalist governments in North America and western Europe, desperately scrambled to carve out sections of African, South American, and Pacific territory for themselves to exploit as North American "nova terra" was nearly exhausted or already claimed.

Since the beginning of the neoliberal period (early 1970s), we've seen the steady re-emergence of gilded-age oligopolistic conditions in the US. Again, somewhat competitive markets, closer to the ideal liberal conception of capitalism, after enough time degenerated again into oligopolistic conditions as earlier winners swallowed up newer smaller losers whole and all firms came to rely more heavily on greater exploitation through austerity at home (Keynesian deficit spending on social services was no longer "sustainable" from the perspective of sustaining profit growth - except military spending, of course) or through imperialism abroad (hence the continued military spending - easier to keep sweatshops and mines operating at gunpoint) to continue growing their profits, leading once again to what Marxists call "late-stage" capitalism.

This is the corrupt "crony" capitalism we're dealing with nowadays and have dealt with for the better share of the past century, one in which the most successful firms are those that were successful decades ago and snowballed into megalithic entities with internal economies larger than those of many developing nations (examples such as Disney and Amazon come to mind), one in which they've been able to successfully buy off politicians most of the time because the government answers to the interests of big capitalists firsts, small capitalists second, and the working class last. While extensive use of antitrust law to break up these almost-monopolistic entities (apparently what "watchdogs" like Elizabeth Warren want) would temporarily cripple their ability to dominate the market and lobby the government, under newly competitive conditions winners always eventually re-emerge and devour the losers. 

The only permanent solution to this problem is to _nationalize_ these mega-corporations and place them under the control of their workers and the voters. Doing anti-trust every few decades is a neverending cycle; solving this requires accepting that these "crony" corps aren't going away and should instead be taken away from their crony capitalist owners, thereby embracing a socialist (or at the very least social-democratic) approach to this problem. Companies like Walmart and Amazon have in their pursuit of profit developed their own internal centrally-planned infrastructure; placing such infrastructure under democratic control, under the people's control, would allow people to democratically plan production and transportation of goods that are desperately needed but which aren't always profitable to give to people who are priced out of buying them.

The US is also uniquely positioned to attempt such nationalization because there is no US military to invade the US to shut it down and force privatization at gunpoint, or impose trade sanctions in retaliation like they've done to social democracies like Venezuela for taking similar measures. US soldiers would have to point their guns at their own fellow Americans to prevent it, and some of them may not be willing to do that.

replies.text:
@muesli_snipes 
Ehhh, its pretty hard to defend the japanese internment camps. 

In canada (i'm using the canadian context because that's the one i was taught, but i imagine the US policy wasn't that different) the policy was very, very racist.

The premise was that because these people had japanese ancestry, despite being second or third generation immigrants, they would sympathize with imperial japan.

Using that basis, the japanese had their property taken (like the jews) and then carted off from the nice and mild BC climate into the frozen hell that is the rocky mountains. The camps were basically wood huts (again like concentration camps) with rationed food, no running water, and forced labour programs for its inhabitants. 
At wars end, these people were released and forced to live in Alberta, which is a much different place than the BC coast.

As I said, everything is infinitely comparable and infinitely distinct; you point out the differences or similarities depending on the point you are trying to make. And if your point is that every society has the capacity for evil, as I said above in the thread, I think that's great and you'll hear no more from me. If you are worried, I'm not sure how: it's hard to be worried about things that already happened. But I think it's just that a dead Japanese-American is useful in a way that a dead Uighur isn't.

Hannah Ahrendts famous interview example of that logic is that of a north german farmer telling his peer in the pub: 
"I mean its pretty clear that those slaw workers deserve it how we treat them, they really are subhuman- if a keep them in the barn, they will steal and eat the fodder from the pig feeder. If that doesnt prove it, what does?". 

People like this use racial self-aggrandisement at the expense of others in need to justify further mistreatment. Its a justification not to employ any empathy at all, that in itself should be a red flag, and not to reflect on ones own actions (like starving ones slave workers) that drove those people to that state in the first place, as well as fallaciously negating the effects of the power imbalance you are trying to justify, namely the people you are responsible for being responsible for actions they have to take out of need, but somehow NOT being responsible for your own response to defend said power structure that also happens to serve you, even if said response is sadistic overreach.

In my eyes its the ultimate loss of humanity, and yet it is so banal and easy. I mean how low can a human being get? 

Its a slippery slope towards more dehumanising policies because it negates any reaponaibility and reflection on part of the perpetrators. And this philosophy is 100% applicable to the justifications on the situation on the southern US border, hence the comparison to the Nazis concentration camp system. I think by, "dismantling ICE and replacing it with something that more reflects our values", she rather means an organization that won't beat and kill migrants or set up Facebook groups where they make racial and xenophobic slurs, which are things that ICE and some Border Patrol agents have done. Also, what's this, concentration camps not being, "logistically viable"? There doesn't really need to be any logistics for them, since the premise of them is to make life miserable, which means depriving those kept thereof sanitary, working facilities, and a half-decent standard of living, which many of them do.

There are plenty of other ways to handle migration, but building and maintaining a country-long wall (with what funds?), and placing migrants in disgusting conditions is not one of them. Also, I can guarantee that whatever problems many on the right-wing claim they're causing, there are domestic entities that cause those problems to a greater degree, i.e. losing jobs because of corporations willing to send them overseas.

The phrase ‚Äúnever again‚Äú doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúsomething this horrible will never again happen‚Äù but rather ‚Äúwe must remain vigilant and oppose any and all pivots towards fascism so these atrocities will never again happen‚Äù. author: @justinreid2947
text: The way Sargon talks about the kids crying at the end is so fitting it's just plain terrifying. I've known so many parents complain about noisy kids like this and it really only takes a shift in reference to turn it into something monstrous. Our society really is in a very bad place and if you call Trump and his movement what it really is (fascism) then the right and center gaslight you by saying "you're overreacting" or "you're ridiculous" or "you're crying wolf". And *thank you* for comparing the rise of the fascist right to bullying because as a bullying victim myself, I was even forced to "apologize" to one of my bullies in eighth grade by a teacher who took a "both sides" approach. In fact the way the far-right plays victim is *exactly* the same way my bullies got the teachers to always take their side, and that experience was my first lesson in how power protects power and condemns the weak to "what it deserves". A very important video yet at the same time it's still so surreal that something like this is happening during my lifetime.

replies.author: @yltraviole
replies.text:
I was bullied too, and the behavior of the far right is so recognizable to me. Especially the way they try to disguise their horrible statements as "jokes", or claim that the left oppresses them when they call out their bullshit. 
The only way to get them to stop harassing me was by using physical violence. Which taught me how important it is to punch natsees.

replies.author: @discountchocolate4577
replies.text:
@paaklapi The most effective antidote to fascist politics is explicitly socialist politics - socialism seeks to meet the needs of working class people frequently getting the short end of the stick under liberalism, while fascists offer false cures for those same needs. Both left and right have the potential to flourish when the status quo becomes unbearable, as it did for Germans after the Treaty of Versailles cratered the German economy. In 1919 German socialists attempted a revolution like the one that had just created the Soviet Union, but social democrats betrayed the German revolution, assassinating leading figures such as Rosa Luxemburg early and (temporarily) preserving the newly formed liberal Weimar republic.
 
With revolutionary socialists incapacitated and social democrats insufficiently able to address German workers' problems, Nazis were able to exploit their growing angry sentiment. The German social democrats were eventually falsely branded "social fascists" by the (justifiably) angry Comintern under Stalin, so an effective antifascist coalition failed to materialize when it was needed most. This allowed the Nazis to win power by blaming scapegoats such as the Jewish and Roma diaspora on the problems of capitalism. In countries like the US, UK, Hungary, Brazil, and India, we're now on a similar path, for lack of sufficiently influential explicitly socialist political forces with humane answers to the problems created by neoliberal economic policy in the aftermath of the 2008 global recession.

text:
I'm not even gonna break down Sargon's points, because his fundamental definition of Concentration camps is just....... wrong. In fact most of these points by Sargon illuminate why learning how the Nazi State worked should basically be mandatory, because people treat Nazi Ideology like an impossible snap of the fingers that drives people Fascist and bloodthirsty, instead of the systemic dismantling of Weimar democracy and one of the *first* parliamentary systems of its time (not to say the the Imperial diet was amazing or anything, but it does demonstrate just to what extent power was consolidated within the Nazi Regime).

The portrayal of systemic elimination as 'necessary' and not necessarily enjoyable is eerily mirrored in the talking points around the detention centers, the lines by which we define "well we're just trying to figure out what's going on" and "well we're not killing them" (funny how Sargon keeps using 'We' despite not being an American, in the administration or anything, almost as if he's referring to a wider group or something) , and clear categorization for a group where what that process entails is evidently afforded more lease, and more methods than would be acceptable with other groups, especially ones that subvert democratic processes that would once have been implacable, now become 'weak and indecisive' and have to therefore be maneuvered around. e.g. Executive Order 13769, 13768 and of course, the Separation of children at the border. Its even easier to do so with Immigration because they don't even have citizens rights to provide a buffer from such federal decisions.

Its easy to see the failures of historical education on the Nazis when the bottom line for comparisons to Concentration camps is outright Industrial scale murder, and not identified by their inherent prerogative to contain a specific segment of a population, it hasn't been 100 years and yet, alot of the edifices of the Nazi Regime are viewed like Historical antiquities with no bearing on modern politics, because for most people the Nazi ideology starts and ends with the Holocaust, not the means by which a small outlier party within the Reichstag's parliament NSDAP party came to control every aspect of German society that had democratized not even 20 years ago

author: @Fraggr92
text:
What i never understood is why people are always so insistent that we don't "humanize" the nazis and the people of Germany before and during WW2.

I'm sorry to break it to you all but the nazis and the people of Germany were human. They were not some kind of lovecraftian abominations or inhuman monsters. They were for the most part regular people who allowed themselves to be hooked by hate and extremist ideals.

People always do that, when something horrific happens they always want to push it away and disassociate themselves from it, claiming that the people responsible are monsters or otherwise "not human".

The way i see it, that act of disassociating from horrible events is harmful because it denies one of the most fundamental facts about being human - that we do horrible things. Repeatedly and consistently. 

Human history is filled with evidence that we do horrible things, yet we want to delude ourselves that we don't. All of those horrible events were not us, it was "the bad-guys", "the monsters" or "the evil ones". We're the good guys, see. We're nothing like them. Right?

But here's the thing - if you manage to convince yourself that you're fundamentally "good" and that your beliefs are right and true, then do you think you would notice if it started to seem like you were not? How far would you have to go before you started questioning yourself? Could you kill someone if you were convinced it was for a good cause? Could you perhaps even kill many people? Could you look away when people were being tortured or raped if you believed it to be necessary or that they somehow deserved it? Do you think that a criminal sees themselves as a monster or even a bad guy? Do you think that the people of Germany did?

In recognizing nazis as human, we don't make their actions any less reprehensible. What it does however allow us to do is to accept the fact that we are all capable of both good and bad, and that it's thus even more important to try our absolute hardest to do good. 

With the exception of very few, people are not born good or evil. Hell, outside of human societies, concepts like good and evil or even morality itself probably don't exist. It is our actions and the beliefs and ideologies that we allow ourselves to adopt that defines whether our peers see us as good or bad. And unfortunately we are all highly susceptible to suggestion.

With this in mind, let me propose an idea. I say that we stop disassociating from the nazis. We stop vilifying them and painting them up to be monsters or inhuman. We don't excuse them, but we own their actions and recognize that they are part of us. We use this knowledge as a tool to check ourselves and make sure that we are not following in their footsteps. Because it is my belief that when a person is actively aware that they have the capacity to do serious harm that they are the most likely to try and do good instead.

replies.author: @Fraggr92
replies.text:
‚Äã@justifiably_stupid4998 Yeah but like Tyler pointed out, most people are not born "evil" either.


Law is important. Without laws we descend into chaos. However how we choose to enforce those laws is up for debate. Many people campaign for harsher and longer punishments for all sorts of different crimes but more and more studies show that oftentimes harsh and long sentences either have no positive effect or have outright negative ones.


As for your view on what laws are there to do, i disagree. Laws are not there to "punish evil" or "reward good". Laws are there to outline what kind of behaviours that society will and will not accept. That's it. It's basically a glorified list of what is and isn't allowed under various circumstances. It's not the law's job to determine what is "good" and what is "evil". If anything i'd say that it's important that the law and those who enforce it try to remain as neutral as possible. 



"Good" and "Evil" are at their core emotional concepts. They are based on how a person's behaviour makes the people around them feel. If people love you, you are good. If people hate you, you are evil. Having a system like the law that is used to determine the lives and futures of living breathing people be based on something as unstable as emotions is a recipe for disaster.


The law should be based on observable and logical fact. Things that can be proven to be true. For example - killing people causes harm to the victim and the people closest to them, therefore it's illegal. Speeding in/on a motorized vehicle increases risk of traffic accidents that have serious consequences for everyone involved, therefore it's illegal.  etc. etc.
Does this mean that a person who has committed one or several of these crimes is necessarily "evil" or that a person that has never committed a crime in their life is necessarily "good"? Of course not. Which is why it's not the job of the law to judge whether someone or something is good or evil.

I hate to be the one to break this to you but if you break the law it doesn't matter if you're an illegal immigrant or a legal citizen, you lose custody of your child. replies.author: @Frosty-oj6hw
replies.text: @CassidyCope No system that involves humans is perfect. None of these problems are particularly unique to border detention facilities. When people break the law you have to have a mechanism that detains them and such a mechanism is always going to have problem. There's no detention facilities, jails, prisons anywhere in the world that aren't subject to things like mistreatement of people, deaths, etc. When you're dealing with people who do not respect the rule of law you unfortunately are left with no other option than to detain them with force, which leads to injuries and sometimes death. Obviously we should strive to make these places as safe as we can do with the budgets that we have, but ironically it's the sheer volume of illegal immigration that means detention camps are often temporary structures and facilities which are not staffed or funded as well as we'd ideally like them to be. It's the illegal behaviour of others that cause these problems, if people simple followed the rule of law none of this would be required. It's not a secret that children are separated from their parents, so the parents coming are knowingly subjecting their own children to that risk, they are the ones morally responsible, they are the ones who choose to break the law or not.

the past three decades, including huge increases in the size of the Border Patrol, the addition of hundreds

to detect illegal entries." -The Migration Policy Institute

A) If this kind of taxpayer money really does go towards border security, why are the conditions to terrible that children are drinking out of toilets and dying?
B) Even if there's some reason for why my source is in some way false, it's a reminder that this could be stopped at any time. The president has the proper executive powers to feed these kids. It could even be how he uses the latest "State of emergency" that he declared, by totally flipping how it looks that he's going to use it and spending the money he can on good things such as literally feeding children.

Other responses:
"People die in police custody all the time." You're normalizing this. I hope you realize that this is how the issue gets worse.
"Are mistreated by guards or other inmates." Misleading. The other kids, when interacting with each other, are actually helping each other. There's little to no abuse between the children; meanwhile, children are being sexually abused by guards and are dying in the shitty conditions of the cages.
"You cannot frustrate the law like this." That doesn't sound a bit police state-ey, not at all.
If you're going to keep on arguing that it's the parents' fault, here's a reminder: humans prioritize. If they're willing to risk being parted from their children, that almost definitely means that they're running north from something that's even worse.

replies.text:
@paaklapi caring for children you learn different cries. Those are exhaustion and hunger and scared cries all mixed together. Not bratty I want my way cries. Its inflection you can't always pick up on being a tangential observer. And even if my kids ARE being brats and crying for attention, I am still concerned and monitor to make sure they are okay. I dont dismiss the crying. Thats neglect and not only is it shitty, its illegal. As someone who was neglected and abused, I'd never do that to my kids. Theres a way to fix spoiled brat-itude without abusing your kids or ignoring them. 

Pro tip for new parents: its saying no calmly and setting boundaries with "if x then y" condition statements.

The _criminal_ elements that Trump is faking concern about, come in by plane, boat or border stations - legally. So what's the point of paying for an expensive plug for areas that won't really benefit from them?

replies.author: @fluidthought42
replies.text:
@30weekoldwomber61
Except the terms "Right" and "Left" in political terms have very distinct meanings. The Left believes in Socialism (or that workers should own the means of production) or agrees with socialist values, while the Right believes in corporatism (or that for profit institutions should keep or be allowed expand their ownership of capital) or agrees with corporatist values. Neoliberalism, for example, agrees with the values of the Right and is not part of the Left. 

So do "authoritarian" and "antiauthoritarian" have agreed upon meanings. Carl, for example, claims to be part of the antiauthoritarian Right. However, it has been documented that extreme antiauthoritarians can be "triggered" into becoming extremely authoritarian. Carl (partly at least because he is dependent on his authoritarian base) has been carrying water for authoritarian practices during the Trump administration. Whether his previous antiauthoritarian attitude was genuine or not, his current behavior follows the signs of being authoritarian.

Any questions?

replies.author: @eila2088
replies.text: @deinvater797 Europe's only open borders is the Schengen Area within the EU and even then it is only for freedom of movement citizens, third party nationals with approved visa/exemption or rare exemptions (ie. Heads of State, some city-states). To enter the area has a border. To enter the borders of those involved that are not within the area has a border. The only countries with "open borders" would be those landlocked within Schengen and even then it is only borderless for those authorized to be in the area. And this is just movement of people, there are different barriers and freedoms for goods or capital to go between European countries borders.
